column1: SEATTLE - There's little lyrical language to be found in the most recent international report on climate change.
column2: What does the report from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change contain?

column1: The document from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) runs to 2,200 pages and is crammed with technical details about greenhouse gas emissions, rising sea levels and atmospheric circulation.
column2: Who was a lead author of the chapter on marine measurements in the IPCC report?

column1: Seattle oceanographer Gregory Johnson was a lead author of the chapter on marine measurements, and even he was having a hard time wrapping his head around the massive compilation.
column2: What did Gregory Johnson decide to do to simplify the understanding of the report?

column1: The result is a virtual booklet that is riding a wave of celebrity on the Web and in the Twittersphere.
column2: How popular has Gregory Johnson's haiku version of the climate change report become on social media?

column1: Seattle oceanographer Gregory Johnson was a lead author of the chapter on marine measurements, and even he was having a hard time wrapping his head around the massive compilation.
column2: What did Johnson use as a basis for his haiku?

column1: Seattle oceanographer Gregory Johnson was a lead author of the chapter on marine measurements, and even he was having a hard time wrapping his head around the massive compilation.
column2: How did Johnson summarize the information on global warming's impacts on ice and snow in the IPCC report?

column1: Where the summary devotes two pages and four graphs to global warming's impacts on ice and snow - a topic that takes up more than 100 pages in the full report - Johnson boils it down to 17 syllables.
column2: What does Johnson's haiku say about the impact of global warming on ice and snow?

column2: What is the message conveyed in the haiku paired with the watercolor of a swing set on a grassy slope?

column1: Seattle oceanographer Gregory Johnson was a lead author of the chapter on marine measurements, and even he was having a hard time wrapping his head around the massive compilation.
column2: Why did Gregory Johnson find the process of creating haikus from the climate change report appealing?

column1: So when a bad cold kept him in the house one weekend, Johnson decided to distill the report to its essence via a centuries-old Japanese art form: haiku.
column2: Who was the intended audience for Gregory Johnson's haiku booklet?
